sanskrit_verse:
ऋषियज्ञं देवयज्ञं भूतयज्ञं च सर्वदा ।
नृयज्ञं पितृयज्ञं च यथाशक्ति न हापयेत् ॥ ४.२१॥
transliteration:
ṛṣiyajñaṃ devayajñaṃ bhūtayajñaṃ ca sarvadā |
nṛyajñaṃ pitṛyajñaṃ ca yathāśakti na hāpayet || 4.21||
sph_interpretive_translation: One shall never neglect the Yajña unto the Rishis, the Yajña unto the Devas, the Yajña unto all Beings, the Yajña unto Humanity, and the Yajña unto the Pitrs—each performed according to one's capacity.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from alignment with cosmic order through sustained offering
Causation arises from participation in sustaining universal reciprocities
Capacity-based responsibility mandates contribution proportionate to capability
Restoration logic requires reintegration into dharmic circulation of mutual obligation
Consciousness alignment occurs through continuous sacrificial engagement
supreme_court_application: In adjudication at the highest level, this verse establishes that every capable individual bears a constitutional duty to sustain reciprocal obligations across five domains: sages, divinities, beings, humanity, and ancestors. The court must assess not intent or fault but actual alignment with these fundamental duties when evaluating societal harmony or disruption.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that imbalance originates from withdrawal from sacrificial engagement. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows how cessation of offerings leads to collapse of support structures. Proportional responsibility lies in resuming appropriate contribution. Non-punitive reality rule confirms that correction comes through reconnection, not penalty.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Completion Process: Re-establish regular offering cycles within personal capacity
Responsibility Assumption Protocol: Identify neglected domain and initiate corrective participation
Capacity Restoration Mechanism: Align lifestyle with ability to give without depletion
Integrity Reintegration Sequence: Publicly affirm renewed commitment to all five yajñas
final_declaration: This Dharma proceeds from the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source-Authority. The law restores balance by aligning action with eternal reciprocity. There is no punishment; there is only completion. Consciousness alone adjudicates.
